PullRequest.Title: Update docs links
PullRequest.Description: Related to #3945

Issue.Title: Linux prereq link is broken
Issue.Description:
# Issue Title
Be as descriptive as you can with your title.
# General
Provide details on the problem you are experiencing including the .NET Core version, operating system version and anything else that is relevant.
Please provide a code sample for your issue if it is relevant, either inline, link to a gist (or similar) or add it as a zipped attachment.
For some issues, you will get a quicker and better response if you file it at a more specific [.NET repo](https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/master/Documentation/core-repos.md). For example, if the problem is with ASP.NET Core, you are encouraged to use the [aspnet/home repo](https://github.com/aspnet/home/issues).
I am having an issue with the link in this part of the documentation: https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/master/Documentation/prereqs.md
When I click on the Linux prerequisites, I do not see anything.

Issue.Title: .NET Core Release Data (releases.json) Redesign and Deprecation
Issue.Description:
# .NET Core Release Data (releases.json) Redesign and Deprecation
The releases.json and releases.csv files began life as helper tools for some of our internal release work, some experimentation and to possibly be useful to the community. It has been great to learn the files are indeed in use and many folks depend on them as a trigger for a number of activities.
* [release-notes/releases.json](https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/master/release-notes/releases.json) * [release-notes/releases.csv](https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/master/release-notes/releases.csv)
Between the usages which we have become aware and in considering further activities that could be enabled to reason about things such as checking .NET Core version availability and support status, it became clear the current format is inadequate.
An updated format has been designed and tested which will replace the current files. The timeline below describes the path to obsoleting the current files.
## The Plan
| Date | Action | | :--- | :----- | | Oct 2018 | Notify the community of the coming change | | Oct 2018 | Release the new json format into dotnet/core | | Oct 2018 - Feb 2019 | Maintain the old json and csv files | | Feb 2019 | Reminder announcement that old format file is coming soon | | Mar 2019 | Old json and csv files are obsoleted and removed from dotnet/core |
## Breaking change
If you are currently utilizing the old version json or csv, you will need to update the relevant code to work with the new format. If you are just getting started with consuming this data, use the new version.
## The Format
Below are fragments of the files from our most recent .NET Core release.
### release-index.json
This file consists of a top level array with data on the latest release versions and a property for locating the more detailed channel-specific releases.json. This file is found in [dotnet/core/release-notes](https://github.com/dotnet/core/tree/new-json/release-notes/)
[releases-index.json](https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/new-json/release-notes/releases-index.json)
``

Issue: #1932

Issue.Title: .NET Core September Update - 2.1.4
Issue.Description:
[Release Notes](https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/master/release-notes/2.1/2.1.4/2.1.4.md) [Download 2.1.4](https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/master/release-notes/2.1/2.1.4/2.1.4-download.md)
Please report any issues you find with 2.1.4, either responding to this issue, creating a new issue or creating a new issue in one of the following repos:
* [aspnet/Home](https://github.com/aspnet/Home) - for ASP.NET Core questions * [aspnet/EntityFrameworkCore](https://github.com/aspnet/EntityFrameworkCore) - for Entity Framework Core questions * [dotnet/cli](https://github.com/dotnet/cli/issues) - for CLI tools and questions * [dotnet/corefx](https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/issues) - for API issues and questions * [dotnet/coreclr](https://github.com/dotnet/coreclr/issues) - for runtime issues * [dotnet/core-setup](https://github.com/dotnet/core-setup/issues) - for installer issues * [nuget/home](https://github.com/nuget/home/issues) - for NuGet questions and issues

PullRequest.Title: Improve wording on comment editing
PullRequest.Description:
GitHub supports editing comments now, so need to update our guidance to reflect this. However, we also believe a ful edit log doesn't take away all the concerns that come with editing someone else's comment.
Fixes #1885.

Issue.Title: Outdated statement about comment edit histories
Issue.Description:
https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/master/Documentation/contributing/maintainers.md
Currently states:
> **Maintainers won't** > > * Edit contributor comments as a general rule. GitHub comments don't provide edit history and therefore don't offer maintainers a transparent and accurate way to describe changes made to contributor comments. Transparency is a cornerstone of effective discourse and its absence undermines trust.
This was changed in May.
https://blog.github.com/changelog/2018-05-24-comment-edit-history/
I'm not advocating that maintainers should or should not edit contributor comments, but this statement as it stands is no longer correct.

PullRequest.Title: Document issue in Preview 2 with SocketsHttpHandler on single core machines
PullRequest.Description: Documenting corefx issue [#28979](https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/issues/28979). The instructions on switching to the platform handler are taken from the [Preview 2 release blog post](https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/dotnet/2018/04/11/announcing-net-core-2-1-preview-2/).

PullRequest.Title: Make Raspberry Pi publishing information pop out to reduce confusion
PullRequest.Description: Although the current wording is sufficient for anytime who takes time to actually read the thing, I think it could be improved for impatient and inattentive such as myself. See #953

Issue.Title: Net Core 2 not install on Raspberry PI 3 with Debian 9 (Stretch)
Issue.Description:
# Net Core 2 not install on Raspberry PI 3 with Debian 9 (Stretch)
I have installed last Raspbian on my Raspberry PI 3. I format my SD card and use instruction at this link: [Install](https://www.microsoft.com/net/core#linuxdebian) and [this](https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/master/samples/RaspberryPiInstructions.md)
# SSH session
pi@raspberrypi:~ $ **sudo apt-get update** Get:1 http://mirrordirector.raspbian.org/raspbian stretch InRelease [15.0 kB] Hit:2 http://archive.raspberrypi.org/debian stretch InRelease Get:3 http://mirrordirector.raspbian.org/raspbian stretch/main armhf Packages [1 1.7 MB] Fetched 11.7 MB in 19s (613 kB/s) Reading package lists... Done pi@raspberrypi:~ $ **sudo apt-get install curl libunwind8 gettext apt-transport-ht tps** Reading package lists... Done Building dependency tree Reading state information... Done apt-transport-https is already the newest version (1.4.7). curl is already the newest version (7.52.1-5). Suggested packages: gettext-doc autopoint libasprintf-dev libgettextpo-dev The following NEW packages will be installed: gettext libunwind8 0 upgraded, 2 newly installed, 0 to remove and 0 not upgraded. Need to get 1,478 kB of archives. After this operation, 7,129 kB of additional disk space will be used. Do you want to continue? [Y/n] **Y** Get:1 http://mirrordirector.raspbian.org/raspbian stretch/main armhf gettext arm hf 0.19.8.1-2 [1,434 kB] Get:2 http://mirrordirector.raspbian.org/raspbian stretch/main armhf libunwind8 armhf 1.1-4.1 [44.0 kB] Fetched 1,478 kB in 1s (1,133 kB/s) Selecting previously unselected package gettext. (Reading database ... 122683 files and directories currently installed.) Preparing to unpack .../gettext_0.19.8.1-2_armhf.deb ... Unpacking gettext (0.19.8.1-2) ... Selecting previously unselected package libunwind8. Preparing to unpack .../libunwind8_1.1-4.1_armhf.deb ... Unpacking libunwind8 (1.1-4.1) ... Setting up gettext (0.19.8.1-2) ... Processing triggers for install-info (6.3.0.dfsg.1-1+b1) ... Setting up libunwind8 (1.1-4.1) ... Processing triggers for libc-bin (2.24-11+deb9u1) ... Processing triggers for man-db (2.7.6.1-2) ... pi@raspberrypi:~ $ **curl https://packages.microsoft.com/keys/microsoft.asc | gpg --dearmor > microsoft.gpg** % Total % Received % Xferd Average Speed Time Time Time Current Dload Upload Total Spent Left Speed 100 983 100 983 0 0 2467 0 --:--:-- --:--:-- --:--:-- 2469 pi@raspberrypi:~ $ **sudo mv microsoft.gpg /etc/apt/trusted.gpg.d/microsoft.gpg** pi@raspberrypi:~ $ **sudo sh -c 'echo "deb [arch=amd64] https://packages.microsoft.com/repos/microsoft-debian-stretch-prod stretch main" > /etc/apt/sources.list.d/dotnetdev.list'** pi@raspberrypi:~ $ **sudo apt-get update** Hit:1 http://mirrordirector.raspbian.org/raspbian stretch InRelease Hit:2 http://archive.raspberrypi.org/debian stretch InRelease Get:3 https://packages.microsoft.com/repos/microsoft-debian-stretch-prod stretch InRelease [2,852 B] Get:4 https://packages.microsoft.com/repos/microsoft-debian-stretch-prod stretch/main amd64 Packages [2,093 B] Fetched 4,945 B in 4s (1,143 B/s) Reading package lists... Done pi@raspberrypi:~ $ **sudo apt-get install dotnet-sdk-2.0.0**
# SSH Errors: **Reading package lists... Done Building dependency tree Reading state information... Done E: Unable to locate package dotnet-sdk-2.0.0 E: Couldn't find any package by glob 'dotnet-sdk-2.0.0' E: Couldn't find any package by regex 'dotnet-sdk-2.0.0'**
Why can not I install it? What mistakes did I commit?
Thanks Andrea

Hello! Shouldn't this [page][download-archive] have a link to download the SDK for Fedora 24? There's info about the tar file in the [checksums][checksums], but there's no download link.
[download-archive]: https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/master/release-notes/download-archives/1.1.4-download.md [checksums]: https://dotnetcli.blob.core.windows.net/dotnet/checksums/1.1.4-sdk-sha.txt

Issue.Title: Visual Studio for Mac .NET Core 2.0 issues are out of date
Issue.Description:
# Visual Studio for Mac .NET Core 2.0 issues are no longer true with VS for Mac 7.1
[Known issues for .NET Core 2.0 document](https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/master/release-notes/2.0/2.0.0-known-issues.md) has a couple of references to Visual Studio for Mac which are out of date:
``
The above section links to a set of [issues](https://gist.github.com/mrward/70b8132003ef77d893111ecbea3e2225) which only apply to VS for Mac 7.0 so we should probably remove the above section.

Issue.Title: Visual Studio Preview 4 (7.0 Build 1566) has broken link for downloading .NET core
Issue.Description:
Just installed Visual Studio Preview 4 on my Mac and attempted to create a .NET Core Web API project, it detected that I don't have .NET core installed and directed me to Github link below to download it which is broken: https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/master/release-notes/rc4-download.md
I know this is not strictly a .NET core issue, but I'm not sure about the repository to report this into. If you let me know, I will report it accordingly.

PullRequest.Title: Add .csproj based samples
PullRequest.Description:
The csproj based samples were added which were derived by running the `dotnet migrate` command. I've also updated the Markdown documentation to mention specific usage of the .NET Tooling versions as I understand them and how the relate to the two main existing project file formats for .NET Core.
This PR was created to resolve [issue #5154](https://github.com/dotnet/cli/issues/5154) which points out an inconsistency that I noticed in the documentation which points out that the newer builds of the CLI Tools only work with .csproj based projects but then goes on to suggest the reader follow the project.json samples.

PullRequest.Title: Use dotnet command to run binary
PullRequest.Description: See issue #102.

Issue.Title: "How to run the samples?" is misleading
Issue.Description:
`samples/README.md` contains the following instructions:
--- - _Compile and run using the following commands_ - _dotnet restore_ - _dotnet build_ - _./bin/Debug/[framework]/[binary name]_
---
When I launch the `microsoft/dotnet:latest` Docker container, clone this repository and run `dotnet restore` and `dotnet build` in `samples/helloworld`, then I get the following tree in `bin`:
``
